conclusion: To determine the speed of the elevator at t = 60 seconds, analyze the acceleration-time graph and integrate acceleration to find velocity.
The graph shows acceleration of the elevator over time; x-axis is time in seconds, y-axis is acceleration in m/s^2.
From t = 0 to t = 1 second: Acceleration increases linearly from 0 to 2 m/s^2.
From t = 1 to t = 4 seconds: Acceleration remains constant at 2 m/s^2.
From t = 4 to t = 5 seconds: Acceleration decreases linearly from 2 m/s^2 to 0.
From t = 5 to t = 55 seconds: Acceleration is 0.
From t = 55 to t = 56 seconds: Acceleration increases linearly from 0 to -2 m/s^2.
From t = 56 to t = 59 seconds: Acceleration remains constant at -2 m/s^2.
From t = 59 to t = 60 seconds: Acceleration decreases linearly from -2 m/s^2 to 0.
Interval 1: From t = 0 to t = 1 second, final velocity is 2 m/s.
Interval 2: From t = 1 to t = 4 seconds, final velocity is 8 m/s.
Interval 3: From t = 4 to t = 5 seconds, final velocity is 6 m/s.
Interval 4: From t = 5 to t = 55 seconds, final velocity is 6 m/s.
Interval 5: From t = 55 to t = 56 seconds, final velocity is 4 m/s.
Interval 6: From t = 56 to t = 59 seconds, final velocity is -2 m/s.
Interval 7: From t = 59 to t = 60 seconds, final velocity is 0 m/s.
At t = 60 seconds, the speed of the elevator is 0 m/s.
